comments.commentBody:
I was a quiet, shy 11-year old who loved drawing & story-telling nearly as much as dancing when Paramount's version of PNB's Nutcracker was filmed, and distinctly remember summoning the nerve to approach "Mr. Sendak" during production breaks to gift him with sketches. (I'd skipped several grades + was a PT home schooler with few non-ballet friends, so used to hide in my school's library between classes or during assemblies where I'd frequently replicate entire idolized Sendak books with a sharpened #2.) He surprisingly always reciprocated with a friendly smile as he ballpoint-penned or sharpied wild dancing beasties on treasured white paper dinner napkins. What a marvelous sport.

After retiring from a professional classical ballet career at 21, I became an illustrator/art director. Sendak definitely influenced this shift.

Ironically a mere 3 weeks ago my inner 'waltz of the wallflowers' resurfaced at a speaking event on memory. "I, uh...haven't asked for a signature since requesting Maurice Sendak's as a child!" I blurted to Joshua Foer of 'Moonwalking with Einstein' fame. "Mine's the copy full of nerdy bookmarks." (An adjacently seated Nobel laureate chuckled as I rouged.) I then audibly hissssed (think Zach Galifianakis' "gay snake") in reaction to learning that Joshua owns a Kindle. Naturally I was mortified and fled as quickly as possible. Joshua's good-humored inscription read: "Happy to be second to Maurice Sendak!"

Mr. Wild Thing...you will be dearly missed.

XOXOX

Send Giants:
An Elegy in 2012

May 8, 2012

Dear Mr. Sendak:

Please tell the lion that you care (even if you don't), and it will maybe let you come back. Speak very loudly because it's dark in there, and according to the newspapers, its mouth is shut tight. And this lion never gets sick when it eats.

Or maybe we can send giants. They can shake you out.

Then the newspapers can print a correction tomorrow, like they do and nobody catches the correction because they're not looking or don't even get the paper the next day and so they keep thinking the wrong thing the reporter wrote. But I'll look for it.

Your Friend,
Erin, age 30

Thank you, J.L. Anderson - wonderful interview. Yes, agreed, all. What a powerful soul. Thank you, Mr. "Sun Deck!" Let the Wild Rumpus start!

Virginia Hammer
Midlantic Theatre Co.
A NJ 501(c)3 nonprofit corp.
Theatre in Renaissance Newark + Schools & Prisons

Many years ago now, Maurice directed me in a production of Really Rosie for his new theater company, The Night Kitchen. I played Johnny. For a large portion of the play, I sat on a "stoop" reading a book. One day during rehearsal, Maurice walked over and whispered in my ear, "Whenever you feel like it, smell it and if you would like...... lick it." He turned and walked back to the director's table. It was to this day the best piece of direction I have ever received. I'm very sad today.

My grandmother called me "Wilde Chia". Yiddish for wild thing.

My aunts said "We'll eat you up, we love you so" as they pinched my cheeks.

I'm a US citizen with a Japanese permanent residence permit. As such, I'm eligible for the Japanese national health care system, a godsend after what I went through as a US resident. At age 58, it's hard to contemplate returning to the US and losing that coverage.

Because of my family and friends in the US, my sincere identification with American culture and society, my gratitude for having been raised in such fortunate circumstances, and basic loyalty, I don't plan to become a Japanese citizen. However, when I see the (largely Republican-led) gridlock in government these days, I must admit I get tempted.

Canada admits 3 categories of immigrants:

** Family members of Canadian citizens
** Political refugees (fleeing for their lives)
** Rich people planning to start a business and hire Canadian employees

Americans with a few bucks in the bank and a Social Security check for $1,000/month or so can visit Canada as a tourist for 6 months out of 12 but do not qualify for citizenship.

How do I know? Guess.
Now I can sleep tonight.

Our western concept of  mental health care is woefully inadequate where resources are plentiful by comparison  let alone a culturally challenging environment. Other forms of treatment should be initiated

Can you please give me an example in any country where you have seen a product (or service) and asked its price and said I will give you 10 times that value? I have yet to see someone do this, no matter how many people preach it.

I quite despise India, and it's everyday trials and inescapable narrow-mindedness. This article, however, reeks of NRI snobbery. And amongst the many breeds of despicable Indians, the NRI is one-such.

The driver quip, the expensive pizza. And then the boo-hooing about de-humanizing. How about actually driving your own car? Or paying your maid, what you think the service deserves? Not the "going rate" and then feel all wronged about your high-class lifestyle. Jeez. You're an Indian in many of the most pitiable ways, and far as you may run, you can't escape that.

Saudis infiltrated al-Qaeda, not the US.  They have a better set of candidates for doing so, in terms of finding people with the appropriate backgrounds (e.g. recommendations from family/tribal members, lack of history of assimilating with Western values, immersion in the Salafi traditions, et al).   However, they're also better at *producing* motivations for al-Qaeda members, e.g. the royal family, their export of Salafism elsewhere, and their internal suppression of even less-threatening dissent.
it was a smart move, until it hit the papers.

The U.S. makes many "smart moves" you will never hear about, Bill, because to do so would compromise the action. Unfortunately, you also have a lot of "dumb" politicians and political commentators more interested in scoring political and rating points by attacking those in charge.

Infiltrate al Qaeda is what the U.S. should have done from the start.

The wars we are spending our blood and treasure on --- and killing innocent civilians in left and right --- are absolutely unnecessary, stupid, and ineffective.

This is the first smart move I have read about the U.S. making since 9/11/2001.

Better yet, have speaker Boehner introduce these job creators to our vastly wealthy tax cut well fare recipients, and show them how to create jobs. They didn't create any from 2001 to 2008.

(the Bush years netted ZERO jobs created in the private sector over eight years. The only way Bush nets any positive job growth over his eight years is by those added to the public sector, except public sector means 'government' jobs and everyone knows that Governments don't create jobs.)

So, it would be nice if those private sector job creating Jordanians would show our private sector how to create jobs.

Okay, okay, I know, they created millions of jobs, just not in the United States. More than likely, those American job creators would end up shipping American jobs to Jordan rather than create some here at home.

Explain to me again why we gave these guys all these trillions and trillions of dollars in tax cuts. I caught the supply side and waited on the demand.
Don't underestimate the tsa and underwear
Simple. Election time.

To bounce33: giveth me a break. The Bush Administration had just about figured out where the restrooms were in 2001 when 9/11 struck -- they were only beginning to START agreeing on policy initiatives and the funding to back them when the planes hit our buildings.

Moreover, Clinton's desire to shore up intelligence services came in his SECOND term, after he eviscerated them in his first, and thought perhaps he'd gone too far (well, YEAH). And Gingrich's Republicans, while they were dealing with trying to bring MANY spending priorities into balance (that resulted in the balanced budget Democrats claim so enthusiastically as theirs), should have made an exception.

Did you even read this article?  Try again.  " American intelligence officials were angry about the disclosure of the Qaeda plot, first reported Monday by The Associated Press, which had held the story for several days at the request of the C.I.A. They feared the leak would discourage foreign intelligence services from cooperating with the United States on risky missions in the future."

If you are suggesting that every piece of good news is now the result of "election year politics", manufactured by a vast PR machine run by President Obama and his minions, stop and think about how crazy that sounds.
The world owes this individual so much.  Undetectable bombs?  Yeah…those need to go away.

In a free-speech nation with more ability than ever via electronic media to leak info - whether true info or info found to be fabricated - anyone (actually it'd have to be any huge group of people in this case) would have to be a real dumbass(es) to try to pass this off if it weren't legit (ever hear of wikileaks?). And it would have to be a huge conspiracy, involving many people and many agencies, where all it'd take is one person to talk to 60 Minutes or something.

Dishonesty aside, I don't think anyone or group would be stupid enough to come even close to thinking it'd be worth making something like this up.

@ Petros - a billion dollars in body scanners rests on the CIA making stuff like this up. Without constant propaganda, Americans might start questioning whether growing opium in Afghanistan is really worth tax dollars and soldiers lives.
...and how can we ever really know whether a word of this is actually true?

Apparently he was not a "double" agent, but simply an agent, who did his job by infiltrating the terrorist group, then taking the bomb to the CIA along with, I suppose, a lengthy report.

The man is a hero. The "double agent" part is apparently a misuse of words by the NY Times.

No that's what the NYPD under Comm. Kelly would do,  he would then hold a major news conference to tell the Media what a good job he was doing and only he alone can keep New York safe.  Then Mayor Bloomberrg would announce that the trial would cost billions of dollars and that lower manhattan would be shut down, except for his friends on Wall Street.  That any OWS Protesters seen anywhere in Manhattan would be subject to arrest in case they might be thinking of going near Wall Street.

He was not a "double agent", only an agent who infiltrated the terrorist group. I am confused as to what is so unusual: do you not have undercover cops in the US? Was there not the SOE in WW2? MI5, MI6, CIA? Instead of waxing incredulous, the readers should be thankful your security services and network is working. An excellent operation, intelligently dealt however the American press needs to get out of the business of endangering these operations and the brave people who place themselves at risk to keep those as yourself safe. Saying thank you would be the gracious thing to do.
It doesn't make sense. The C.I.A. foiled its own double agent? They provided the amplification system to create a terrorist, did so, and then took him down when he became one?

To Netanel, and ANYONE ELSE who wants to politicize this pro-soccer article beyond belief: 1.) The article was a thank you to early soccer pioneers.  The title "Vienna's Gift to the U.S." referred to the "soccer gift", that a traveling soccer squad gave to US soccer fans (and future US soccer fans).  Whatever your personal politics today, and the squad's personal politics or aims then, the reference was to early soccer awareness and culture, and the impact it left on fans of the sport here, both new, and immigrant, those who missed the game from their homelands.  Leave sport to sport, and as with all ultras of any stripe, nation, or religion, ALL OF YOU, leave your politics at the doorstep when you come to the GOAL blog.  We talk soccer here.  Of course it veers into the real world, and politics, but if you cross over to that point, respectfully leave, and go to a more fully political blog to continue your political discussions.  The Middle East crisis and the Israeli-Palestinian situation will not be solved here, and those of us who do not care for it to become part of our daily soccer lives will not welcome or tolerate it.  This is the American soccer way.  I look to my fellow USA soccer supporters to back me up here...sound off Sam's et al...

Even after the wrenching experiences of watching Ruffian, Eight Belles, Barbaro and other losses (including Bobina this past weekend), I'm another girl who just loves horse racing...with fifty years of Derby Day with no interruptions allowed on that day....
Breeders Cup day too.
I even spooked my parents spending one summer working with the horses at Arlington Park in Chicago.
'Raised' at Arlington Park I like to say and am now happily retired at Del Mar (racetrack).
Enjoyed your article...I hope there are enough little Paiges to take the sport forward.
Connie

Ma'am, I work two jobs to get through college, as well, in addition to taking almost twenty credit hours and they would make nowhere NEAR enough money to pay my way through college without scholarships or loans. If you want to go to a college or university these days—which, everyone should have an option to do—it is borderline impossible to do so without a some sort of scholarship/loans.

If you think we should value the education of each individual in this nation, then our government needs to make access to higher education the highest priority. If not, then you are ripping a diploma out of the hands of half my classmates. I hope you don't want to do that, ma'am, because this country will look very different in thirty years if you do.

C.Pugh.....You failed to include:

The minimum wage in 1985 was $3.35/hr x 40 hrs =$134/wk x 52 wks = $6968/yr before taxes. (source: Wikipedia) We worked very hard, no doubt about it.

Every generation discovers there are no guarantees. In another 25 years you will be, I'm guessing close to 50, good luck on your journey.
They're not even doing a real filibuster.  Make them make speeches on the floor for hours on end.  That way they won't have time to raise money or run for re-election.
